Fig. 1 Pt/SiO2 ratio of the encapsulated samples (measured by XRF) as a function of the Pt/SiO2 ratio employed in the synthesis gel. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD diffraction patterns of the Pt_NaA samples. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM analysis of the Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH sample: (a,b) Before the thermal treatment; (c,d) After the thermal treatment. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM images of the as synthesized (a,b) NaA_CH; (c,d) Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH; (e,f) Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH; (g,h) Pt(0.2)_NaA_CH, samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 SEM images of the Pt(0.5)_NaA_MW sample. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM images of the (a) Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH and (b) Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH samples. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM images of the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample for different zones. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XPS spectra for fresh powder after thermal treatment in Ar and reduction in H2 at 503 or 673 K. (a) Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx. (b) Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Pt/Si atomic ratio as a function of the bulk Pt/Si ratio for the Pt_NaA encapsulated samples. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 CO conversion at 573 K and 673 K. GHSV = 9421 h−1 and H2O/CO = 2. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Stability test at 673 K and 503 K, H2O/CO = 2, GHSV = 9421 h−1, for the Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH and Pt(0.5)_NaA_MW samples. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Diffractograms of the used catalyst. Fig. 12 Table 1 Chemical composition of the catalysts by XRF. Table 1 Sample Metal loading[wt. %] Experimental ratio Si/Al Pt/Al Na/Al NaA_CH -- 1.19 -- 1.13 Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH 2.17 1.18 0.17 1.08 Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH 1.54 1.18 0.12 1.14 Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH 0.63 1.21 0.05 1.07 Pt(0.2)_NaA_CH 0.16 1.17 0.01 1.22 Pt(0.5)_NaA_MW 0.54 1.24 0.04 1.09 Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx 0.60 1.22 0.03 1.06 Table 2 Surface composition of the fresh catalysts after thermal treatment in Ar and reduction at 503 or 673 K. Sergio Moreno b John Múnera a Laura Cornaglia a Ana M. Tarditi a ⁎ a Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica, INCAPE, Universidad Nacional del Litoral, CONICET, Facultad de Ingeniería Química, Santiago del Estero, 2829, 3000 Santa Fe, Argentina Instituto de Investigaciones en Catálisis y Petroquímica INCAPE Universidad Nacional del Litoral CONICET Facultad de Ingeniería Química Santiago del Estero, 2829 Santa Fe 3000 Argentina b Centro Atómico Bariloche, 8400 S.C. de Bariloche, Argentina Centro Atómico Bariloche 8400 S.C. de Bariloche Argentina ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Pt catalysts were prepared by encapsulating the active metal in the NaA zeolite structure. The catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis using two heating sources, conventional heating through a thermal bath and microwave radiation. The synthesis time was significantly reduced using microwave radiation without affecting the crystallinity or metallic content of the solids obtained. By X-ray diffraction the presence of the pure NaA zeolite phase was confirmed in all the samples. XRD, XPS and TEM results suggested the presence of Pt particles preferentially located inside the crystalline structure. Pt_NaA catalysts were active and selective for the water gas shift reaction at 673 K. No methane formation was detected in any of the samples under the reaction conditions studied. The Pt_NaA catalyst with low Pt content (0.6% wt.) achieved a high conversion of CO (ca. 70%). Keywords Hydrothermal synthesis Encapsulation NaA zeolite Water gas shift 1 Introduction Zeolites are crystalline aluminosilicates which have a microporous structure with elevated thermal stability and high chemical resistance. The most common applications of zeolites in the chemical industry have been separation and purification. In the last 20 years, environmental and biopharmaceutical applications have also become important [1]. One of the most important properties of zeolitic materials is their ion exchange capacity; this property makes zeolites suitable for their application in detergents, nuclear, metals removal, and recovery industries, among others. Future applications of the zeolites will include their use as molecular sieves, functional powders in the removal of odors, plastic additives, and composites. Zeolites have been widely applied in catalysis, mainly in petrochemical processes due to their small pore size capable of carrying out selective catalysis. At present, zeolites are applied as supports of metals or oxide clusters in many catalytic processes [2]. Particularly, the Linde type A zeolite (LTA with Na, Ca or K cations) is one of the most widely used due to its highest cation exchange capacity associated with its high Al content. In recent years, the NaA zeolite has been reported as support for the reverse water gas shift reaction [3], ethanol steam reforming [4] and in the selective CO oxidation [5]. For the selective CO oxidation, the Pt supported zeolite catalysts have shown higher selectivity than the Pt supported alumina catalysts. This enhancement was possible due to the small pore size of the zeolites that provided a “molecular sieve effect” [6]. On the other hand, Pt-KLTL catalysts promoted by potassium showed a beneficial effect over conversion and selectivity in the reverse water gas shift reaction [3]. Usually, the incorporation of metal or oxides into the zeolite structures has been performed by post-synthesis treatments as ion-exchange or impregnation in which, the amount of metal to be incorporated is limited by the exchange capacity of the zeolite and its pore volume. Adding the metal precursors into the synthesis gel allows the encapsulation of a higher amount of metal or oxide clusters on the zeolite structures, with the advantage of a higher resistance to large cluster formation [2]. One of the main challenges in the application of this method is to avoid the precipitation of the metal precursor in the highly basic media; the precursor has to be stable at the required conditions for the hydrothermal process. Common methods for encapsulating metal complexes in zeolite structures involve the use of flexible ligands or templates [7,8]. For example, the addition of mercaptosilane ligands has been studied in order to avoid metal precipitation and improve the dispersion of small metal particles in the zeolite structure [9,10]. Recent studies have reported the effectiveness of encapsulating metal particles in zeolites to avoid sintering and improve the catalytic performance in many processes. The encapsulation method allows the incorporation of metal particles into the zeolite NaA structure in one step during the hydrothermal synthesis. Usually, the catalysts employed in the water gas shift (WGS) reaction use reducible oxides as supports, such as ceria, titania or zirconium, which may reach high conversions [11]. Platinum has been one of the most widely studied noble metals. However, the formulations based on supported noble metals could suffer a relatively rapid deactivation and produce significant amounts of methane under the reaction conditions of the WGS [12]. Metal sintering and carbon deposition were the main cause of the deactivation of these catalytic systems [12]. The Pt/ceria catalyst suffered a rapid deactivation under feed conditions of the typical outlet reformer composition due to the reduction of CeO2 in the presence of H2 [13]. Other systems, like Pt/TiO2, presented deactivation due to metal sintering at 573 K [14]. A promising alternative to perform the WGS reaction is the use of a membrane reactor (MR) where hydrogen production and purification are coupled in a unique device [12]. Commonly, the membranes used in MRs for hydrogen production are Palladium-based, which operated at a temperature higher than 673 K. In this way, the challenge for an efficient operation of the membrane reactor is to find active and selective catalysts, without carbon formation and membranes with high permeability and selectivity. In this study, Pt-NaA catalysts were synthesized by the direct addition of a suitable Pt precursor in the synthesis gel without using ligand substances. The Pt content was optimized and microwave was used as alternative heating source. The solids were characterized by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), X-Ray Fluorescence Spectrometry (XRF), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The evaluation of the catalyst in the Water Gas Shift reaction was carried out at 673 K. 2 Experimental 2.1 Zeolite NaA synthesis The hydrothermal synthesis was carried out on a polypropylene vessel heated by a thermal bath. The molar composition of the gel was the same as the one used in a previous work [15]. First, 3.85 g of NaOH and 3.03 g of Na2Al2O4 were dissolved in 60 ml of deionized water (vessel 1). Then, 1.78 g of silica powder (Aerosil 200) was mixed in 26.70 mL of deionized water (vessel 2). Both vessels containing the aluminate and silica precursors were separately immersed in the thermal bath at 363 K during 15 min for their homogenization. After 15 min, solution 1 was added to suspension 2 to obtain the synthesis gel and, then, the hydrothermal synthesis was carried out at 363 K during 8 h under constant stirring. The solids were collected by filtration and washed with deionized water until the rinse liquid reached neutral pH. The final product was dried in an oven at 353 K overnight. 2.2 Pt encapsulated into NaA zeolite structure An aluminosilicate gel with the same composition as that used for the pure NaA zeolite synthesis was prepared. Pt/Al2O3 molar ratios of 0.048, 0.030, 0.012 and 0.006 were studied using Pt[(NH3)4]Cl2 as the metal precursor. Pt[(NH3)4]Cl2 was dissolved in 2 mL of H2O and added dropwise to the gel at 333 K under continuous stirring. After that, the gel was homogenized by magnetic stirring at 333 K for 1 h. Then, the synthesis procedure was the same as that of the pure NaA zeolite. Additionally, one sample was synthesized in an autoclave of teflon® using microwave radiation, employing the same procedure but reducing the synthesis time to 1 h at 363 K and employing a Pt/Al2O3 ratio = 0.012. For comparison, a sample prepared by ionic exchange (Pt/Al2O3 = 0.012) was studied. For this purpose, 1 g of zeolite powder previously synthesized was mixed with a solution 0.5 mM of Pt during 24 h at room temperature. Then, the powder was filtered, washed and dried in an oven overnight. The nomenclature used follows the next scheme: Pt(wt%)_NaA_X_Y, where X refers to the heating source (CH for conventional heating and MW for microwave heating) and Y to the Pt incorporation method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction were measured using an XD-D1 Shimadzu instrument, with Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation at 30 kV and 40 mA. The scan rate was 1°.min−1 in the 2θ = 5 – 60° range. The morphology of the powder catalysts was observed by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM); the images were obtained using a JEOL model JSM-35C equipment. The metal content of the prepared samples was measured by X-ray fluorescence using a Shimadzu EDX-720 equipment. The quantification was performed considering the Na Kα, Al Kα, Si Kα and Pt Lα emission lines. Transmission electron microscopy was used to measure the metal cluster size and its dispersion. A Tecnai F20 G2 UT microscope operated at 200 kV was used. Samples for TEM were prepared by diluting the powders in ethanol and dropping the solution on lacey carbon films without sonication in order to avoid any modification of the sample. Thermal analysis experiments were carried out in a Mettler Toledo DSC 821e in order to find out the energetic changes that take place during the treatments of the solids. The surface properties of the catalyst were studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy using a multi-technique system (SPECS) equipped with a dual Mg/Al X-ray source and a hemi-spherical PHOIBOS 150 analyzer operating in the fixed analyzer transmission (FAT) mode. The spectra were recorded in the constant pass energy mode at 30 eV and the X-ray source was operated at 150 W and 11 kV. The working pressure in the analyzing chamber was less than 5 × 10−9 kPa. Before introducing the samples into the main chamber of the spectrometer, they were heated up in vacuum at 423 K; then, they were reduced in H2 at 673 K during 10 min in the load-lock chamber. The Al 2p, Si 2p, Na 1 s, C 1 s and Pt 4f spectra were recorded for each sample. All binding energies (BE) were referred to the C 1 s line at 284.6 eV. The peak areas were determined by integration employing a Shirley-type background. Peaks were considered to be a mixture of Gaussian and Lorentzian functions. Sensitivity factors provided by the instrument manufacturer (SPECS) were used to determine the surface composition. 2.4 Catalytic test using a fixed-bed reactor The water gas shift reaction was conducted in a conventional catalytic fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure and temperatures of 573 K and 673 K. The feed stream gas mixture was made up of 22% CO, 44% H2O and Ar (balance). The catalysts powders (400 mg) were diluted with inert ground quartz (70 mesh) in a ratio of 1:1 to avoid channeling effects. Prior to use, the Pt catalysts were heated up to 673 K (0.5 K min−1) in Ar flow and kept at this temperature during 1 h for the salt decomposition; then reduced in situ in flowing H2 at the same temperature for 2 h. CO and Ar were fed through MKS mass flow controllers; steam was generated in a preheater fed with water from a syringe pump (Apema S.R.L.) at the desired flow rate. The gases leaving the reactor flowed through an ice-cooled trap and a tube packed with silica gel to remove water before the gas chromatographic analysis. The feed and product streams were analyzed with a Shimadzu 9 A chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a HayeSep D column for the complete separation of the gaseous components. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and properties The present work reports the formation of Pt clusters within a NaA zeolite structure by a simple synthesis method such as the encapsulation of metal complexes. Two heating sources (conventional and microwave) were also evaluated. Six catalysts were prepared employing several Pt compositions in the synthesis gel. Table 1 shows the Si, Al, Na and Pt content measured by XRF for each powder and its comparison with the pure NaA zeolite prepared using the same gel composition. In order to study the influence of the synthesis method on the incorporation of Pt within the zeolite structure, the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample was prepared by ion exchange with the same Pt content as the Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH, and Pt(0.5)_NaA_MW samples prepared by encapsulation. For all the samples the experimental Si/Al ratio determined from XRF measurements was similar to the theoretical value of the zeolite NaA framework (Si/Al˜1). Analyzing the metal content in the zeolite framework and the Pt concentration in the synthesis gel, it was possible to observe that for higher metal concentrations, the Pt loading did not show a significant increment. Fig. 1 shows the comparison between the Pt/SiO2 ratio for the encapsulated samples and the ratio employed in the synthesis gel. Note that for the samples with the higher Pt content, Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH and Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH, a significant deviation was observed with respect to the ratio used in the synthesis. This could suggest a limit in the Pt incorporated on the zeolite (under the synthesis conditions here employed); although the concentration of the precursor salt in the synthesis gel increased, the Pt could not be retained in the crystalline structure. Iglesia et al. [2] reported a Pt content of 0.76 wt. % by the encapsulation method using a 0.048 Pt/Al2O3 ratio; in our work, we achieved 2.2 wt. % of Pt for the same Pt/Al2O3 ratio. On the other hand, Iglesia et al. [16] also reported the encapsulation of 5 wt.% of Co2+ complexes by the use of a compound with alkoxysilane groups which served as a linkage to the incipient LTA frameworks [16]. However, the high content of ligated precursors led to the formation of amorphous solids. Crystalline phases obtained after synthesis were identified by XRD analysis. Fig. 2 shows the diffraction patterns of the synthesized samples without previous treatment. Note that the powders with low Pt content, Pt(0.2)_NaA_CH and Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH, exhibited all the peaks corresponding to the pure zeolite NaA, without reflections assigned to other phases. The characteristic reflection of Pt was only detected in the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample, where the peak located at 39.4°, assigned to Pt (111), was observed [5]. For the encapsulated samples, the Pt reflections were not observed in any case, indicating that the Pt particles are inside the crystalline structure or that small Pt clusters are present. Short range XRD patterns (2θ = 35°-45°) of the samples with 0.6 wt.% were compared in the Figure S1 (Supplementary Information). Iglesia et al. [2] studied the encapsulation of several metals in the NaA zeolite and also reported the absence of large metal crystallites even after thermal treatments. In the samples with higher Pt content, Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH and Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH, the presence of two additional peaks located at 2θ of 28.0° and 51.0° was observed, which are characteristic of the NaP structure [17]. The incorporation of the Pt precursor into the synthesis gel during the hydrothermal treatment could promote the coexistence of phases or a transition to a more stable one. Naskar et al [18]. reported a coexistence of the NaA to NaP phases at 373 K only by changing the synthesis time and using the same molar composition. After the treatment in Ar at 673 K during 1 h, followed by a reduction in pure H2 at 673 K for 2 h, the XRD results showed the disappearance of the NaP zeolite (Figure S2) and the presence of an amorphous halo, indicating the occurrence of a small amount of amorphous material. Mikula et al. [19] reported the presence of an amorphous halo in NaA zeolite with high Pt content (3.91%), and the formation of nanosized rough crystals. Considering the changes observed by XRD in the Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH sample, a thermal analysis was carried out following the transformation of NaP into the NaA phase (Figure S3). In addition to the endothermic peaks caused by the dehydration of the sample, the analysis showed that an endothermic event took place at ˜720 K and it could be related to the structure transition [17]. This transition may be due to the fact that the NaP zeolite is less stable with temperature compared with the NaA zeolite. Li et al. [17] studied the phase transitions of the NaP zeolite caused by thermal treatments. The authors performed in situ XRD measurements and concluded that from 673 K the NaP phase disappeared; this result was confirmed by the TGDSC data which showed a structure transition between 673 and 1073 K. This could explain the behavior observed by XRD for the Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH and Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH samples after the calcination and reduction treatments (Figure S2). Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of the Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH sample before and after the thermal treatment. The typical cubic crystals of the NaA zeolite covered by smaller particles which may correspond to the NaP phase were observed on the fresh sample (Fig. 5 a and b). As it is known, the crystalline morphology of the NaP zeolite can have different shapes, such as wool balls or walnut shells [17,18]. After treatment at 673 K, the presence of nanosized crystals on the surface of large cubes was observed in the same sample (Fig. 5 c and d). Other authors reported the formation of nanosized cubic crystal when the Pt content was high (3.91%) [19]. Fig. 4 compares the morphology of the Pt(1.6) _NaA_CH, Pt (0.6) _NaA_CH and Pt(0.2)_NaA_CH samples with that of a conventional NaA zeolite (NaA_CH). The cubic morphology of the NaA zeolite was observed in all the powders. The Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH sample still presented a small portion of agglomerate of zeolite NaP attached on the surface of the cubic crystals. For lower Pt contents, only cubic crystals were observed, in agreement with the XRD data (Fig. 2). On the other hand, a decrease in the crystal size was observed with the increment in the Pt content. Mikula et al. [19] reported the formation of nanosized crystals with the increment of the Pt content in the zeolite structure. The authors reported the presence of nanosized (0.4-0.5 μm) and rough crystals of zeolite NaA for samples with a Pt content of 3.91%. The roughness was attributed to the formation of agglomerates of even smaller cubes, lower than 20 nm in size. A change in the morphology of the Pt_NaA zeolite crystals was observed for the Pt(0.5)_NaA_MW sample. The samples that were synthesized through conventional heating presented cubes with truncated edges, while the sample synthesized by microwave had perfect edges and the presence of a higher amount of small cubes (Fig. 5 ). It is known that the synthesis conditions (silica and alumina sources, temperature, time, heating source) have a strong effect on the morphology of the zeolite crystal [20]. The Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH and Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH samples were studied by TEM. Fig. 6 includes TEM images, which clearly show the presence of Pt nanoparticles lying on the surface of the crystals. The corresponding size distribution is included in the inset. It can be seen that the range of both histograms is approximately the same, the distribution of the sample Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH being broader than that of Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH. In the Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH sample the resulting nanoparticles are monodispersed. Size distributions were also used to calculate the dispersity index (DI), given by the ratio of the surface averaged to the number-averaged diameter. (1) D I = d T E M d n (2) d T E M = ∑ n i d i 3 / ∑ n i d i 2 (3) d n = ∑ n i d i / ∑ n i Where: n i : is the number of clusters with diameter di d T E M : surface average diameter d n : number average diameter The DI parameter gives an idea of the uniformity of the cluster size; values higher than 1.5 correspond to polymodal clusters and values near 1.0–1.5 are assumed as monodisperse distributions [2,9]. From the surface averaged diameter, the metal dispersions (D) can be estimated. D is defined as the fraction of Pt atoms exposed on cluster surfaces. (4) D = ( 6 ν m / a m 〈 d T E M 〉 ) Where: νm : is the bulk atomic density of Pt (15.10 × 10−3 nm3) am : is the area occupied by a Pt atom on a polycrystalline surface (8.07 × 10−2 nm2) The DI values obtained for the Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH and Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH samples are near the unity (1.12) indicating the high uniformity of the cluster size. The size uniformity and TEM images suggest that the Pt particles are within the crystalline structure of zeolite NaA. However, metal clusters larger than the NaA zeolite cages were observed in all the samples. As it was reported by Iglesia et al. [2], the formation of local lattice defects around the growing metal clusters could take place. The zeolite recrystallization process would also repair any structural defects, being very difficult the detection of defects by XRD or TEM. The powder prepared by ion exchange shows the formation of large agglomerates of Pt in the crystal surface of zeolite NaA. This result confirms those observed by XRD (Fig. 2). The diffraction pattern of the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample presented a peak corresponding to Pt(111). The effect of the reduction temperature on the Pt species was studied by XPS surface analysis of the fresh catalyst (without reaction test). The samples were treated at 673 K in Ar for 1 h and reduced in pure H2 at 503 K or 673 K for 2 h. Prior to the measurement, the powders were heated at 503 K or 673 K on H2(5%)/Ar during 10 min in the pretreatment chamber of the equipment. In the XPS spectra presented in Fig. 8, the Pt 4f-Al 2p and Na 2 s region is shown for the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx (Fig. 8a) and Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH (Fig. 8b) samples. In a first attempt, the samples were reduced at 503 K in pure H2 to avoid the sintering of the Pt particles. After reduction at 503 K the XPS spectra showed the presence of Pt0 (BE Pt 4f7/2 = 70.7 eV) and Pt2+ (BE Pt 4f7/2 = 72.7 eV) for both samples. The Pt0/Pt2+ surface ratio for the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx and Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH powders was determined; the sample prepared by ion exchange presented a higher value (Pt0/Pt2+ = 4.9) compared with the encapsulated sample (Pt0/Pt2+ = 0.63). This result can be related to the presence of Pt particles preferentially on the surface of the crystals in the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample, which could indicate a higher reducibility of the metal particles. After reduction at 673 K no peaks related to Pt2+ were observed in the XPS spectra for both samples. Table 2 shows the Si/Al, Pt/Al and Na/Al ratios and the binding energies of Pt 4f7/2, Al 2p, Si 2p and Na 1 s. Comparing the Pt/Al ratios obtained by XRF (Table 1) and XPS (Table 2) for the catalyst prepared by ion exchange, the surface ratio (Pt/Al = 0.058) was slightly higher than the bulk (Pt/Al = 0.05). This difference suggests that the Pt particles were preferentially located at the surface of zeolite crystals in agreement with the TEM observations. Due to the small size of the NaA zeolite, the incorporation of the metal precursor by ion exchange is difficult. Farrusseng and Tuel [21] reported that for pore sizes of ca. 0.55 nm, the incorporation of metal cluster is limited by the small pores, which leads to large particles mainly located on the external surface. The catalysts synthesized by the encapsulation method (Table 2) presented a lower Pt/Al surface ratio comparing with the volumetric ratio (Table 1), suggesting that the Pt was mainly located in the zeolite structure with a low amount on the crystal surface. Therefore, the encapsulation method allowed a high incorporation of Pt particles into the crystalline zeolite structure. The Pt/Si atomic surface ratio as a function of the bulk ratio is plotted in Fig. 9. Note that for the samples with a Pt content of 1.6% or lower, a linearity between the surface and bulk Pt/Si ratio can be observed. These data could suggest the presence of Pt particles with uniform size, homogeneously distributed. The Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH sample with the higher Pt/Si ratio shows a deviation, which could be related to the presence of Pt particles with different sizes or polyatomic particles. On the other hand, the XPS Pt/Si atomic ratios were considerably lower than the bulk Pt/Si ratios; which indicates that Pt particles were homogeneously distributed in the entire zeolite surface area and not only in the external area [22]. Kaliaguine et al. [23] reported an extension of the Kerkhof-Moulijn model to understand the surface intensity ratio of metal supported zeolite catalyst. In their approach, the dispersion and surface segregation effects were taken into account, considering the presence of two different particle sizes. The authors highlighted the importance of both effects (dispersion and segregation) because they occur simultaneously in many zeolite-supported oxides and metal systems. 3.2 WGS reaction The samples prepared were employed as catalysts for the WGS reaction at 573 K and 673 K in a fixed-bed reactor using a H2O/CO = 2 and a GHSV = 9421 h−1. All catalysts were heated at 673 K (0.5 K min−1) in Ar atmosphere for the decomposition of the metal precursor. Reduction was carried out in pure H2 during 2 h at 673 K according to the XPS results (Table 2). Fig. 10 shows the CO conversion for all the catalysts studied at 573 and 673 K; CH4 production was not detected in any case. An increment in the CO conversion with the increase of temperature was observed for all catalysts. The Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH sample with higher Pt content exhibited the highest conversion of CO (96%) at 673 K; the lowest conversion was obtained with the Pt(0.2)_NaA_CH catalyst. A similar conversion of CO (˜65%) was observed for the catalysts with 1.6% and 0.6% Pt, which suggests that the Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH and Pt(0.5)_NaA__MW samples had a better performance because they had smaller Pt content. Catalytic tests at 573 K exhibited a moderate conversion of CO except for the Pt(2.2)_NaA_CH sample due to the high Pt content, which presented a conversion of 70% at 573 K. The Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample achieved a ˜46% of CO conversion, while Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH and Pt(0.5)_NaA_MW presented a conversion of ˜65% under the same conditions evaluated. The lower conversion for the ion exchanged sample could be due to the sintering of Pt particles on the crystal surface observed by TEM (Fig. 7 ). On the other hand, comparing the turnover frequency of the catalysts with 0.2, 0.6 and 1.6 wt.% of Pt at 573 K (CO conversion lower than 15%, close to differential conditions), the most active catalyst was the Pt(0.2)_NaA_CH. The activity followed the order Pt(0.2)_NaA_CH > Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH > Pt(1.6)_NaA_CH, which values were 2007 h−1, 1121 h−1 and 558 h−1 respectively. These results could indicate that the activity was related to the particle size. In the samples prepared by the encapsulation of the Pt particles inside the crystalline structure, a confinement effect (isolated Pt particles) could be produced with high dispersion and uniform size. Due to this effect, Iglesia et al. [2] reported a catalytic system based on noble metal clusters within the LTA structure which presents a noticeable resistance against thermal sintering. Zhang et al. [3] encapsulated Pt within the LTL structure, reporting a significant improvement in the catalytic performance of the RWGS reaction. The authors remarked the beneficial effect over the metal dispersion and thermal stability of the encapsulation method, which contributed to the high selectivity in the reaction test. In our study, the encapsulation of Pt within the NaA zeolite was successfully applied to prepare active catalysts for the WGS reaction, obtaining high conversions and hydrogen selectivity. Few papers have reported the use of zeolites as supports for the WGS reaction [24–27]. Flytzani-Stephanopoulos et al. [26] studied the effect of Na addition to Pt catalysts (prepared by incipient wetness impregnation) supported on zeolites KLTL and MCM-41. They found that the addition of Na to the Pt-KLTL catalyst significantly improved the activity, suggesting that the high Na content in the NaA zeolite could have a positive effect on the WGS reaction. Davis et al. [28] reported the positive impact of the alkali cations (K and Na) on the low temperature water gas shift rates. From DRIFTS studies, the authors found that the formate decomposition rate significantly increase with the alkali addition due to the weakening of the formate C–H bond [28]. The Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH and Pt(0.5)_NaA_MW samples were subjected to a stability test under the conditions employed. Fig. 11 shows the CO conversion as a function of time on stream for the Pt(0.6)_NaA_CH and Pt(0.6)_NaA_MW samples. The catalysts were also submitted to heating/cooling cycles. First, the samples were evaluated at 573 K; then, the temperature was increased at 673 K and the reaction was carried out for several hours. Finally, the reactor was cooled down to 573 K (in Ar) and then the reactants were fed. In this case, the CO conversion was equal to the initial value. The stability of supported catalysts becomes a critical issue to their catalytic application; the Pt_NaA catalysts were stable at least during 15 h in WGS reaction, and without methane formation at any time during the reaction. This result could be related to the high dispersion of Pt particles (avoid sintering) obtained with the encapsulation method. Table 3 shows the binding energy and surface atomic ratios for the used catalysts. The Pt_NaA encapsulated samples presented the same Pt/Al ratio for the fresh and used powders (Table 2 and 3 ). This result suggests that during the reaction tests the sintering of metallic particles did not occur. On the other hand, the Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample showed a decrease in the Pt/Al ratio for the used powder, which indicated the sintering of the Pt particles in agreement with the lowest conversion of CO observed in the reaction test. Fig. 12 shows the XRD diffraction patterns of the used catalysts. The Pt(0.6)_NaA_IEx sample shows the presence of the peak corresponding to Pt (111), with a higher intensity compared with the fresh powder (Fig. 2) and the appearance of the Pt (200) reflection (JCPDS 01-087-0640). The absence of bulk Pt metal peaks in the encapsulated samples, even after reaction test at 673 K, reflects the good stability of Pt particles in agreement with the XPS and TEM results. 4 Conclusions A hydrothermal synthesis procedure was developed for the encapsulation of platinum clusters within NaA zeolite crystals without the use of a linkage or stabilizing substances. An important reduction of synthesis time was achieved by the microwave heating of the gel, obtaining a good crystallinity and the same Pt content. The XRD, XPS and TEM results suggest the presence of the Pt particles within the zeolite NaA structure. Treatment in Ar at 673 K and reduction in H2 at the same temperature allowed obtaining Pt0 as active phase with a good dispersion and thermal stability. The encapsulation method allowed obtaining Pt-NaA catalysts active for the WGS reaction. The characterization of the used catalysts (XPS, DRX) indicated that none of the encapsulated samples presented the sintering of the Pt particles. All the encapsulated Pt-NaA catalysts studied in this work were stable at 673 K and H2O/CO = 2. The reaction tests showed high conversions of CO and 100% of selectivity to H2. Besides, catalysts with a Pt content of 0.6% achieved conversions near 70% and exhibited good stability for at least 15 h in reaction with no methane formation during the test. Acknowledgments The authors wish to acknowledge the financial support received from UNL, CONICET, and ANPCyT. María Belén Gilliard is thanked for the XRF measurements. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apcata.2018.12.034. coredata.dc:description: Pt catalysts were prepared by encapsulating the active metal in the NaA zeolite structure. The catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis using two heating sources, conventional heating through a thermal bath and microwave radiation. The synthesis time was significantly reduced using microwave radiation without affecting the crystallinity or metallic content of the solids obtained. By X-ray diffraction the presence of the pure NaA zeolite phase was confirmed in all the samples. XRD, XPS and TEM results suggested the presence of Pt particles preferentially located inside the crystalline structure. Pt_NaA catalysts were active and selective for the water gas shift reaction at 673 K. No methane formation was detected in any of the samples under the reaction conditions studied. The Pt_NaA catalyst with low Pt content (0.6% wt.) achieved a high conversion of CO (ca. 70%).
coredata.dc:title: Pt encapsulated into NaA zeolite as catalyst for the WGS reaction
